extraction_metadata.focus: Michael Johnson (d. 1718) and immediate family - primary source records
extraction_metadata.notes: This extraction focuses on records with actual citations. Tony's research notes and theories are captured separately.

documents.title: Thomas Mims Patent - 500 acres Tuckahoe Creek
documents.location_description: on the south side of the main branch of the Tuckahoe Creek
documents.transcription_excerpt: Thomas Mims.....500a.. (N L)...Henrico Co; on the south side of the main branch of the Tuccahoe (Cr); adj. Wm Burton; Benja Woodson; Michael Johnson...Pat bk 10, page 217, paid 50 S.

people.reasoning: Only Thomas Mims documented at Tuckahoe Creek
Need to determine which William Burton - possibly son of Robert Burton
Benjamin Woodson (1666-1723) documented as Quaker at Tuckahoe Creek area
Only Michael Johnson documented at Tuckahoe Creek; White Oak DNA anchor

documents.title: Michael Johnson Patent - 500 acres Tuckahoe Creek
documents.location_description: on the S. side of the main br. of the Tuckahoe Cr
documents.transcription_excerpt: Michael Johnson records a land patent of 500a (N L) Henrico Co; on the S. side of the main br. of the Tuckahoe Cr; adj. Benja. Harrison's survey; John Woodson's Mill Cr; and Thomas Mim's land. Paid 50 shill. Book 10 pg 345.

people.reasoning: White Oak DNA anchor; only Michael Johnson at Tuckahoe Creek
Benjamin Harrison - need to identify which one; Harrison survey referenced
John Woodson's Mill Creek referenced - Tony notes 'This is John Woodson of Arrowhattocks'
people.research_note: Need to determine which John Woodson - multiple in area

people.reasoning: Same Thomas Mims from 1714 patent

documents.notes: Tony notes: 'This area is now in Goochland County'

documents.title: Inventory of Estate of Michael Johnson
documents.transcription_excerpt: Michael Johnson...Inventory..of Estate.. Recorded in a court held for Henrico County the fifth day of October 1719, John and James Johnson presented this Inventory upon oath which was thereupon written to record...Test..Henry Wood, Dep

people.reasoning: White Oak DNA anchor; this confirms death by August 1719
Presented inventory with James Johnson; consistent with being sons
Presented inventory with John Johnson; consistent with being sons
Deputy clerk; Tony notes involvement with Robert Burlington of Arrowhattocks

documents.notes: This document is critical - it confirms Michael Johnson's death and that John and James Johnson presented the inventory (strongly suggesting they were his heirs/sons)

documents.title: Will of John Watson
documents.transcription_excerpt: Dated 30 Jul 1702. Rec. 1 Feb 1706. Henrico Co VA. Will of John Watson names wife Alice. Sons John, Joseph, and Benjamin. Daughter Sarah, wife of Michael Johnson (who received 1 shilling). Wife Alice to receive Cowtale Quarter. After her death, her share to son John. The whole being 478 acres by patent. John to receive 1/2 the above plantation and 100 acres, part of tract of 195 acres on the east side of the north branch of Upham Brook, part of tract taken up by James More. Son Joseph, 400 acres on Chickahominy Swamp, part of greater tract bought of Thomas Cocke, Sr. and 200 acres S side the Swamp, part of 480 acres patented 21 Apr 1690, to adjoin the land he lives on. To son Benjamin, the plantation, one half of 478 acres, after death of my wife, 50 acres S side Chickahominy Swamp at Upham Brook, 95 acres east side north branch of Upham Brook, part of 195 acres, and 280 acres S side Chickahominy Swamp part of 480 acres. to daughter Sarah, wife of Michael Johnson, 1 shilling.

people.reasoning: Father of Sarah Watson, wife of Michael Johnson
Wife of John Watson; maiden name unknown
Son of John Watson; received half of 478 acre plantation
Son of John Watson; received 400 acres on Chickahominy Swamp
Son of John Watson; received plantation after wife's death
CONFIRMED: Will explicitly states 'daughter Sarah, wife of Michael Johnson' - this is primary source evidence
CONFIRMED: Will explicitly names him as husband of Sarah Watson

documents.notes: CRITICAL DOCUMENT: This will provides CONFIRMED evidence that Sarah Watson was the daughter of John Watson and wife of Michael Johnson. The 1 shilling bequest is notably small - may indicate she had already received her portion, or family tension.

documents.title: St. Peters Parish Vestry Book - Tithables Report
documents.transcription_excerpt: 27 February 1702/3, O. S., p. 55 [renumbered p. 57; Chamberlayne, p. 89] Peter masse upon his motion to this vestrey is ordered to his tithables the tithables on Mr Edloes plantation John Jones and Michaell Johnson

people.reasoning: Peter Massey - reported the tithables
Listed with Michael Johnson on Edloe Plantation tithes; Tony identifies as brother-in-law
White Oak DNA anchor; this places him at Edloe Plantation in 1702

documents.notes: Tony interprets this as showing Michael Johnson and John Jones moved from St. Peters Parish lands to Edloe Plantation area in 1702. The brother-in-law relationship to John Jones is stated by Tony but NOT confirmed by this document.

relationships_to_add.evidence_summary: Watson Will (1702) explicitly names 'daughter Sarah, wife of Michael Johnson'
Watson Will (1702) names Sarah as his daughter

1718 patent shows James Johnson adjacent to Michael Johnson; 1719 estate inventory shows John and James Johnson presenting Michael Johnson's estate inventory together - strongly suggests they were his sons, but no document explicitly states 'son of Michael Johnson'

1718 patent shows John Johnson adjacent to Michael Johnson; 1719 estate inventory shows John and James Johnson presenting Michael Johnson's estate inventory together - strongly suggests they were his sons, but no document explicitly states 'son of Michael Johnson'
Both presented Michael Johnson's estate inventory in 1719; adjacent landowners in 1718 patents; if both are sons of Michael, they are siblings

associations_to_add.evidence_summary: St. Peters Parish vestry book lists both on Edloe Plantation tithes, February 1702/3
associations_to_add.notes: Tony states John Jones was Michael Johnson's brother-in-law, but this document does not confirm that relationship

associations_to_add.evidence_summary: Thomas Mims patent (1714) lists both as adjacent landowners
Michael Johnson patent (1717) lists Thomas Mims as adjacent

Named as son in John Watson will (1702); received half of 478 acre plantation
Named as son in John Watson will (1702); received 400 acres on Chickahominy Swamp
Named as son in John Watson will (1702); received plantation after wife's death
Named as adjacent landowner in Thomas Mims patent (1714)

new_people_to_create.evidence: Named as adjacent landowner in John Johnson and James Johnson patents (1718)

new_people_to_create.evidence: Named as adjacent landowner in James Johnson patent (1718)
Named in St. Peters Parish vestry book as reporter of tithables (1702)

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Tony states John Jones was Michael Johnson's brother-in-law, but no document has been found confirming this relationship. The 1702 parish record places them together but does not state the relationship.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Find document stating relationship between John Jones and Michael Johnson or Sarah Watson

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Tony states that John Johnson and James Johnson are sons of Michael Johnson and Sarah Watson. The 1718 patents show them as adjacent landowners to Michael Johnson, and the 1719 estate inventory shows them presenting Michael's estate. This strongly suggests parent-child relationship but no document explicitly states 'son of Michael Johnson'.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Find Michael Johnson's will or deed explicitly naming John and James as sons

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Tony references a 1685 deed: 'Edward Hatcher of Varina Parish lands sold to Robert Burton adjoining Jonathan Woodson, Michael Johnson and John Johnson on North side of James River in 1685'. Tony notes: 'Lost the Original document on this I need the proof on this deed.'
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Locate the original 1685 deed in Henrico County records to verify Michael Johnson's presence that early

research_notes_not_evidence.note: Tony states Michael Johnson was 'living by Beaverdam Swamp' in 1698 before moving to Edloe Plantation in 1702. No citation provided for the 1698 location.

The 1 shilling bequest to Sarah Watson in John Watson's will is notably small compared to her brothers. Tony does not explain this. Possible interpretations: she already received her portion; family estrangement; standard practice for married daughters; or the family was not wealthy.
research_notes_not_evidence.research_needed: Compare with other contemporary wills for context on bequests to married daughters

possible_claims_for_review.claim: William Burton (adjacent to Michael Johnson 1714) is the son of Robert Burton of Arrowhattocks
possible_claims_for_review.recommendation: Add to research questions - need to find Burton genealogy documentation

possible_claims_for_review.claim: Charles Evans was a 'Welsh Indian' of Arrowhattocks
possible_claims_for_review.recommendation: Interesting if true - 'Welsh Indian' could mean Melungeon or mixed heritage; needs verification

extraction_summary.key_finding: Watson Will (1702) provides CONFIRMED evidence that Sarah Watson was daughter of John Watson and wife of Michael Johnson. Estate inventory (1719) strongly suggests but does not confirm John and James Johnson were sons of Michael.
